00059 /**
00060  * \addtogroup Utilities
00061  * \brief Support routines.
00062  *
00063  * \description
00064  *
00065  *    This module containes various utilities for general computing purposes.
00066  *    So far these include a few functions to process path strings to 
00067  *    get base file names, extension, etc. (see below) and also macros
00068  *    and routines for scientifically dealing with floating point numbers
00069  *    (see \ref PublicFloatingPoint).
00070  */
00071 
00072 /**
00073  * \ingroup Utilities
00074  * \defgroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00075  * \brief Some useful constants and floats comparisons routines.
00076  *
00077  * \description 
00078  *
00079  *   It is important to be aware that errors can creep
00080  *   into calculations using non-integers (floating point numbers) because
00081  *   these numbers cannot necessarily be stored exactly in the computer,
00082  *   and because of roundoff errors and ignorance of the number
00083  *   of significant digits. Generally computations are done with more
00084  *   precision than is needed to minimize roundoff errors. However, errors
00085  *   from some numeric operations can still cause havoc. One particular
00086  *   operation is subtraction (see Subtraction and Comparing Floats in
00087  *   this chapter).
00088  *
00089  *   Some useful constants are defined in the C library file, float.h:
00090  *   
00091  *   *_EPSILON (where * = FLT, DBL, or LDBL) 
00092  *   is defined as the difference between 1.0 and the smallest number
00093  *   greater than 1.0 than can be represented as that type. This gives
00094  *   a measure of the granularity of the each type. FLT_EPSILON is
00095  *   on the order of 10^-7 and DBL_EPSILON is on the order of 10^-16.
00096  *
00097  *   *_DIG (where * = FLT, DBL, or LDBL) is the maximum possible number of 
00098  *   (decimal) significant digits that can be stored in that type.
00099  *
00100  *   *_MAX (where * = FLT, DBL, or LDBL) is the maximum number representable
00101  *   by that type (order of 10^38 for FLT and 10^308 for DBL). If you
00102  *   try to increase this number, you get Inf (infinity).
00103  *
00104  *   *_MIN (where * = FLT, DBL, or LDBL) is the minimum normalized number
00105  *   for that type (order of 10^-38 for FLT and 10^-308 for DBL). 
00106  *   This is not the minimum number representable (that number is
00107  *   *_MIN times *_EPSILON and is on the order of 10^-45 for FLT and
00108  *   10^-324 for DBL). Instead, this is the minimum number that can still
00109  *   have the full number of significant digits for that type.
00110  *
00111  *   (Note that because ints can be stored exactly, there are no corresponding
00112  *   constants in float.h.)
00113  *
00114  * \modifications
00115  *   2002-JUN-24  W Koegler  Touched up.
00116  *
00117  * -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00118  *
00119  * Subtraction and Comparing Floats 
00120  *
00121  *
00122  * \modifications
00123  *   2002-JUN-24  W Koegler  Touched up.
00124  *
00125  * \description 
00126  *
00127  *   Subtraction is an arithmetic operation that
00128  *   can lead to the loss in the number of significant digits. For example, 
00129  *   2.00 - 1.99 (both have 3 significant digits) is equal to 0.01 (one
00130  *   significant digit), not 0.010. These means that the results of a
00131  *   subtraction operation can be highly sensitive to roundoff errors.
00132  *   For instance, if 2.00 is stored as 1.995 in the computer, and 
00133  *   1.99 is stored as 1.994, then the difference is 0.001.  Or if 2.00
00134  *   is stored as 2.004 and 1.99 is stored as 1.985, then the difference
00135  *   is 0.019. The answer with roundoff error can range from twice as
00136  *   large as the real answer to 10 times too small. 
00137  *
00138  *   This problem (loss of significant digits)
00139  *   becomes more pronounced as the two numbers
00140  *   being operated on approach equality. Therefore it is often
00141  *   advisable to test such an operation before deciding what to do
00142  *   with the results. For the operation 
00143  *
00144  *   a - b = c ,
00145  *
00146  *   if
00147  *
00148  *   |(c/a)| < epsilon 
00149  *
00150  *   (where |x| is the absolute value of x), and epsilon is some very small 
00151  *   number,
00152  *   then a and b are approaching equality and we may want to do
00153  *   something special with the results. Often this means assuming
00154  *   a = b, and c = 0.
00155  *
00156  *   One practical application is testing whether a and b are equal
00157  *
00158  *   if |(a-b)/a| < epsilon, then a = b.
00159  *
00160  *   CAVEAT-Unfortunately, if either a or b are zero, we have problems.
00161  *   If a = 0, we have a divide by zero and our test will always
00162  *   fail because x/0 = Inf > epsilon. If b = 0, then a/a = 1 and again
00163  *   our test will always fail. Sometimes we will be comparing
00164  *   a really really small number to 0, and expect them to be
00165  *   equal, but the above test will always fail!!!
00166  *
00167  *   If one value is zero, if they are equal the other one will
00168  *   be close to zero. Close to zero would be defined as
00169  *   |b| < almost_zero. Choice of almost_zero will be problem dependent,
00170  *   but a good guess would be FLT_MIN and DBL_MIN from float.h.
00171  *
00172  *   So now our procedure is to first test if a or b is equal to zero.
00173  *   If that is true, our test becomes
00174  *
00175  *   if |a-b| < almost_zero, then a = b = 0
00176  *
00177  *   and if neither a or b are equal to zero, then we can use our original test
00178  *
00179  *   if |(a-b)/a| < epsilon, then a = b.
00180  *
00181  *   Another practical application is to set the result of subtracting
00182  *   two similar numbers to zero. This will help prevent propagation of
00183  *   roundoff error in following calculations.
00184  *
00185  *   If |c/a| < epsilon, then c = 0.
00186  *
00187  *   Choosing epsilon will depend on the particular circumstances. It
00188  *   will depend on how strict you want to be, how many significant
00189  *   digits you should expect the values to have, how much roundoff
00190  *   error may have crept in, etc.
00191  *
00192  *   Some helpful constants can be found in the C library file, float.h
00193  *   (see the introduction to this chapter). Below are are some 
00194  *   specific examples.
00195  *
00196  *   A constant times *_EPSILON may be appropriate. Another possibility
00197  *   is to use 
00198  *
00199  *   epsilon = 10^(-1 * FLT_DIG)   (or DBL_DIG).
00200  *
00201  *   Typically *_EPSILON (where * = FLT, DBL or LDBL) will be too stringent 
00202  *   as round off errors can accumulate in previous calculations. 
00203  *   For example, a set of ci's, ci = ai + bi, i = 0 .. 10, where calculated
00204  *   with ai and bi provided as randomly generated floats. 
00205  *   The largest value of |(c - a - b)/c|
00206  *   seen was 4.7e-8. However, more operations are done such as
00207  *   |((c^2 - a^2 - 2*A*B - b^2)/c)/c|, the largest value seen was 1.3e-7.
00208  * 
00209  * --------------------------------------------------------------------------
00210  *
00211  *  Precision of Mixed Type Operations 
00212  *
00213  *
00214  * \modifications
00215  *   2002-JUN-24  W Koegler  Created. 
00216  *
00217  * \description
00218  *
00219  *   Here a '?' is symbol for any operation (+, -, *, etc.)
00220  * 
00221  *   INT ? FLT -> FLT
00222  *
00223  *   INT ? DBL -> DBL
00224  *
00225  *   FLT ? DBL -> FLT
00226  *   
00227  *   However, precision is not explicitly carried with floating point numbers.
00228  *   So when that number is passed from the current context, it may suddenly
00229  *   acquire more significance. (E.g. is the product of a float and a
00230  *   double is stored in a double, that double really has the precision of
00231  *   a float, but who can tell? Code should check the types and store
00232  *   the result in a float.)   
00233  *
00234  *   A full description of error propagation analysis is beyond the
00235  *   scope of this documentation.
00236  *
00237  *   \todo Add more documentation? 
00238  *
00239  * --------------------------------------------------------------------------
00240  *
00241  * I/O of Floating Point Numbers 
00242  *
00243  *
00244  * \modifications
00245  *   2002-JUN-24  W Koegler  Created.
00246  *
00247  * \description 
00248  *   
00249  *   If you want to keep the precision of a double, you should write
00250  *   all of it's digits.
00251  *
00252  *   When writing human readable I/O where you care about the number
00253  *   of significant digits, use %g and specify the number of
00254  *   significant digits as '.x' where x is the number of significant
00255  *   digits. Be aware that %g will drop trailing zeros. %g also
00256  *   automatically switches between decimal or scientific notation
00257  *   depending on a variety of factors. If you care about significant
00258  *   digits, never use %f, but %e might be o.k.
00259  *
00260  *   Example: "%11.6g" is used in the library to print floats.
00261  *   The '.6' part says, 'use 6 significant digits' and the '11'
00262  *   says 'try to fit it in 11 characters' (if it doesn't fit it just
00263  *   takes more room) (use '-11' to get left justified). Lets say we have
00264  *
00265  *   float a = 1.1, b = 222.222, and c = 0.000987643;
00266  *
00267  *   then 'printf("%11.6g %11.6g %11.6g)' will print (spacing may not 
00268  *   be correct)
00269  *
00270  *
00271  *   12345678911 12345678911 12345678911 (count spaces 1 to 11)
00272  *
00273  *           1.1     222.222 9.87643E-04
00274  *  
00275  *   and 'printf("%11.6f %11.6f %11.6f)' will print
00276  *   
00277  *      1.10000x  222.222xxx    0.000987         
00278  *
00279  *   where the 'x' are digits outside of the significant digit range
00280  *   and are probably garbage. Note that "%11.15g" is used in the
00281  *   library to print doubles. This will try to fit 15 significant
00282  *   digits into 11 characters, which is fine if there are lots
00283  *   of trailing zeros. If there are not trailing zeros, it will
00284  *   take at least 15 characters of space as needed.
00285  *
00286  *   For portable regression testing, you should not write out more than
00287  *   the number of significant digits because there is likely to
00288  *   be differences in the non significant digits. However, differences
00289  *   in the significant digits may also show up if there is more round
00290  *   off error on another machine.
00291  */
00292 
00293 /**
00294  * \ingroup Utilities

00296  * \brief Various routines for decomposing file paths.

00304 /** \name General purpose floating point comparisons. */
00305 //-------------------------------
00306 //@{
00307 
00308 /**
00309  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00310  * \brief Test if two doubles are equal.
00311  *
00312  * \description
00313  *
00314  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00315  *    error. See FC_VALUE_EQUIV and \ref PublicFloatingPoint for an explanation
00316  *    of what eps and min mean.
00317  *
00318  * \modifications
00319  *    - 01/04/05 WSK moved from threshold here.
00320  */ 
00321 int fc_eq(
00322   double x,    /**< first value */
00323   double y,    /**< second value */
00324   double eps,  /**< smallest distinquishable difference between values */
00325   double min   /**< smallest value distinquishable from zero */
00326 ) {
00327   return FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, eps, min);
00328 }
00329 
00330 /**
00331  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00332  * \brief Test if two doubles are not equal.
00333  *
00334  * \description
00335  *
00336  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00337  *    error. See FC_VALUE_EQUIV and \ref PublicFloatingPoint for an explanation
00338  *    of what eps and min mean.
00339  *
00340  * \modifications
00341  *    - 01/04/05 WSK moved from threshold here.
00342  */ 
00343 int fc_neq(
00344   double x,    /**< first value */
00345   double y,    /**< second value */
00346   double eps,  /**< smallest distinquishable difference between values */
00347   double min   /**< smallest value distinquishable from zero */
00348 ) {
00349   return !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, eps, min);
00350 }
00351 
00352 /**
00353  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00354  * \brief Test if the first double is less than the second double.
00355  *
00356  * \description
00357  *
00358  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00359  *    error. See FC_VALUE_EQUIV and \ref PublicFloatingPoint for an explanation
00360  *    of what eps and min mean.
00361  *
00362  * \modifications
00363  *    - 01/04/05 WSK moved from threshold here.
00364  */ 
00365 int fc_lt(
00366   double x,    /**< first value */
00367   double y,    /**< second value */
00368   double eps,  /**< smallest distinquishable difference between values */
00369   double min   /**< smallest value distinquishable from zero */
00370 ) {
00371   if (x < y && !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, eps, min))
00372     return 1;
00373   else
00374     return 0;
00375 }
00376 
00377 /**
00378  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00379  * \brief Test if the first double is less than or equal to the second double.
00380  *
00381  * \description
00382  *
00383  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00384  *    error. See FC_VALUE_EQUIV and \ref PublicFloatingPoint for an explanation
00385  *    of what eps and min mean.
00386  *
00387  * \modifications
00388  *    - 01/04/05 WSK moved from threshold here.
00389  */ 
00390 int fc_lteq(
00391   double x,    /**< first value */
00392   double y,    /**< second value */
00393   double eps,  /**< smallest distinquishable difference between values */
00394   double min   /**< smallest value distinquishable from zero */
00395 ) {
00396   if (x < y || FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, eps, min))
00397     return 1;
00398   else
00399     return 0;
00400 }
00401 
00402 /**
00403  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00404  * \brief Test if the first double is greater than the second double.
00405  *
00406  * \description
00407  *
00408  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00409  *    error. See FC_VALUE_EQUIV and \ref PublicFloatingPoint for an explanation
00410  *    of what eps and min mean.
00411  *
00412  * \modifications
00413  *    - 01/04/05 WSK moved from threshold here.
00414  */ 
00415 int fc_gt(
00416   double x,    /**< first value */
00417   double y,    /**< second value */
00418   double eps,  /**< smallest distinquishable difference between values */
00419   double min   /**< smallest value distinquishable from zero */
00420 ) {
00421   if (x > y && !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, eps, min))
00422     return 1;
00423   else
00424     return 0;
00425 }
00426 
00427 /**
00428  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00429  * \brief Test if the first double is greater than or equal to the second value.
00430  *
00431  * \description
00432  *
00433  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00434  *    error. See FC_VALUE_EQUIV and \ref PublicFloatingPoint for an explanation
00435  *    of what eps and min mean.
00436  *
00437  * \modifications
00438  *    - 01/04/05 WSK moved from threshold here.
00439  */ 
00440 int fc_gteq(
00441   double x,    /**< first value */
00442   double y,    /**< second value */
00443   double eps,  /**< smallest distinquishable difference between values */
00444   double min   /**< smallest value distinquishable from zero */
00445 ) {
00446   if (x > y || FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, eps, min))
00447     return 1;
00448   else
00449     return 0;
00450 }
00451 
00452 //@}
00453 
00454 /** \name Float versions of floating point comparisons. */
00455 //-------------------------------
00456 //@{
00457 
00458 /**
00459  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00460  * \brief Test if two doubles are equal, assuming float precision.
00461  *
00462  * \description
00463  *
00464  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00465  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00466  *
00467  * \modifications
00468  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00469  */ 
00470 int fc_eqf(
00471   double x,    /**< first value */
00472   double y     /**< second value */
00473 ) {
00474   return FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, FLT_EPSILON, FLT_MIN);
00475 }
00476 
00477 /**
00478  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00479  * \brief Test if two doubles are not equal, assuming float precision.
00480  *
00481  * \description
00482  *
00483  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00484  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00485  *
00486  * \modifications
00487  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00488  */ 
00489 int fc_neqf(
00490   double x,    /**< first value */
00491   double y    /**< second value */
00492 ) {
00493   return !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, FLT_EPSILON, FLT_MIN);
00494 }
00495 
00496 /**
00497  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00498  * \brief Test if the first double is less than the second double,
00499  *    assuming float precision.
00500  *
00501  * \description
00502  *
00503  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00504  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00505  *
00506  * \modifications
00507  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00508  */ 
00509 int fc_ltf(
00510   double x,    /**< first value */
00511   double y     /**< second value */
00512 ) {
00513   if (x < y && !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, FLT_EPSILON, FLT_MIN))
00514     return 1;
00515   else
00516     return 0;
00517 }
00518 
00519 /**
00520  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00521  * \brief Test if the first double is less than or equal to the second double,
00522  *    assuming float precision.
00523  *
00524  * \description
00525  *
00526  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00527  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00528  *
00529  * \modifications
00530  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00531  */ 
00532 int fc_lteqf(
00533   double x,    /**< first value */
00534   double y     /**< second value */
00535 ) {
00536   if (x < y || FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, FLT_EPSILON, FLT_MIN))
00537     return 1;
00538   else
00539     return 0;
00540 }
00541 
00542 /**
00543  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00544  * \brief Test if the first double is greater than the second double,
00545  *    assuming float precision.
00546  *
00547  * \description
00548  *
00549  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00550  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00551  *
00552  * \modifications
00553  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00554  */ 
00555 int fc_gtf(
00556   double x,    /**< first value */
00557   double y     /**< second value */
00558 ) {
00559   if (x > y && !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, FLT_EPSILON, FLT_MIN))
00560     return 1;
00561   else
00562     return 0;
00563 }
00564 
00565 /**
00566  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00567  * \brief Test if the first double is greater than or equal to the second
00568  *     value, assmuming float precision. 
00569  *
00570  * \description
00571  *
00572  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00573  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00574  *
00575  * \modifications
00576  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00577  */ 
00578 int fc_gteqf(
00579   double x,    /**< first value */
00580   double y     /**< second value */
00581 ) {
00582   if (x > y || FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, FLT_EPSILON, FLT_MIN))
00583     return 1;
00584   else
00585     return 0;
00586 }
00587 
00588 //@}
00589 
00590 /** \name Float versions of floating point comparisons. */
00591 //-------------------------------
00592 //@{
00593 
00594 /**
00595  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00596  * \brief Test if two doubles are equal, assuming double precision.
00597  *
00598  * \description
00599  *
00600  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00601  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00602  *
00603  * \modifications
00604  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00605  */ 
00606 int fc_eqd(
00607   double x,    /**< first value */
00608   double y     /**< second value */
00609 ) {
00610   return FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN);
00611 }
00612 
00613 /**
00614  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00615  * \brief Test if two doubles are not equal, assuming double precision.
00616  *
00617  * \description
00618  *
00619  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00620  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00621  *
00622  * \modifications
00623  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00624  */ 
00625 int fc_neqd(
00626   double x,    /**< first value */
00627   double y    /**< second value */
00628 ) {
00629   return !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN);
00630 }
00631 
00632 /**
00633  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00634  * \brief Test if the first double is less than the second double,
00635  *    assuming double precision.
00636  *
00637  * \description
00638  *
00639  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00640  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00641  *
00642  * \modifications
00643  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00644  */ 
00645 int fc_ltd(
00646   double x,    /**< first value */
00647   double y     /**< second value */
00648 ) {
00649   if (x < y && !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN))
00650     return 1;
00651   else
00652     return 0;
00653 }
00654 
00655 /**
00656  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00657  * \brief Test if the first double is less than or equal to the second double,
00658  *    assuming double precision.
00659  *
00660  * \description
00661  *
00662  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00663  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00664  *
00665  * \modifications
00666  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00667  */ 
00668 int fc_lteqd(
00669   double x,    /**< first value */
00670   double y     /**< second value */
00671 ) {
00672   if (x < y || FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN))
00673     return 1;
00674   else
00675     return 0;
00676 }
00677 
00678 /**
00679  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00680  * \brief Test if the first double is greater than the second double,
00681  *    assuming double precision.
00682  *
00683  * \description
00684  *
00685  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00686  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00687  *
00688  * \modifications
00689  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00690  */ 
00691 int fc_gtd(
00692   double x,    /**< first value */
00693   double y     /**< second value */
00694 ) {
00695   if (x > y && !FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN))
00696     return 1;
00697   else
00698     return 0;
00699 }
00700 
00701 /**
00702  * \ingroup PublicFloatingPoint Floating Point Comparisons
00703  * \brief Test if the first double is greater than or equal to the second
00704  *     value, assmuming float precision. 
00705  *
00706  * \description
00707  *
00708  *    This performs a comparison that takes into account floating point
00709  *    error. See \ref PublicFloatingPoint for more information.
00710  *
00711  * \modifications
00712  *    - 06/21/06 WSD Created.
00713  */ 
00714 int fc_gteqd(
00715   double x,    /**< first value */
00716   double y     /**< second value */
00717 ) {
00718   if (x > y || FC_VALUE_EQUIV(x, y, DBL_EPSILON, DBL_MIN))
00719     return 1;
00720   else
00721     return 0;
00722 }

00724 //@}

00726 /**
00727  * \ingroup FilePathUtilities
00728  * \brief Get the dirname in a path string.
00729  *
00730  * \description
00731  *
00732  *    Returns the part of the path before the last slash (ignoring trailing
00733  *    slashes). For example "/usr/local/bin" -> "/usr/local" or
00734  *    "../../cherry.txt" -> "../.." or "grumpy.xslt" -> ".".
00735  *
00736  *    User is responsible for freeing the returned string.
00737  *  
00738  *    If no path is provided, this routine returns NULL.
00739  *
00740  * \modifications
00741  *    - 7/14/2005 WSD Created.
00742  */ 
00743 char* fc_getDirname(char* path) {
00744   char* temp_path;
00745   char* temp_str;
00746   char* dir;
00747 
00748   // early return
00749   if (path == NULL)
00750     return NULL;
00751   
00752   // Use C library function to get dir
00753   temp_path = (char*)malloc((strlen(path)+1)*sizeof(char));
00754   strcpy(temp_path, path);
00755   dir = dirname(temp_path);
00756 
00757   // copy, cleanup & return
00758   temp_str = (char*)malloc((strlen(dir)+1)*sizeof(char));
00759   strcpy(temp_str, dir);
00760   free(temp_path);
00761   return temp_str;
00762 }
00763 
00764 /**
00765  * \ingroup FilePathUtilities
00766  * \brief Get the basename in a path string.
00767  *
00768  * \description
00769  *
00770  *    Returns the part of the path after the last slash (ignoring trailing
00771  *    slashes). For example "/usr/local/bin" -> "bin" or
00772  *    "../../cherry.txt" -> "cherry.txt" or "grumpy.xslt" -> "grumpy.xslt".
00773  *
00774  *    User is responsible for freeing the returned string.
00775  *
00776  *    If no path is provided, this routine returns NULL.
00777  *
00778  * \modifications
00779  *    - 7/14/2005 WSD Created.
00780  */ 
00781 char* fc_getBasename(char* path) {
00782   char* temp_path;
00783   char* temp_str;
00784   char* base;
00785 
00786   // early return
00787   if (path == NULL)
00788     return NULL;
00789   
00790   // Use C library function to get base 
00791   temp_path = (char*)malloc((strlen(path)+1)*sizeof(char));
00792   strcpy(temp_path, path);
00793   base = basename(temp_path);
00794 
00795   // copy, cleanup & return
00796   temp_str = (char*)malloc((strlen(base)+1)*sizeof(char));
00797   strcpy(temp_str, base);
00798   free(temp_path);
00799   return temp_str;
00800 }
00801 
00802 /**
00803  * \ingroup FilePathUtilities
00804  * \brief Get the root of a basename in a path string.
00805  *
00806  * \description
00807  *
00808  *    Returns the part of the path after the last slash (ignoring trailing
00809  *    slashes) minus any extension. For example "/usr/local/bin" -> "bin" or
00810  *    "../../cherry.txt" -> "cherry" or "grumpy.xslt" -> "grumpy".
00811  *
00812  *    The user can specify whether the extension starts with the
00813  *    first "." (0) or the last "." (1). For example, "bundle.tar.gz"
00814  *    would be "bundle" or "bundle.tar". A leading "." is not treated
00815  *    as an extension ".". For example. ".cshrc" -> ".cshrc";
00816  *
00817  *    User is responsible for freeing the returned string.
00818  *
00819  *    If no path is provided, this routine returns NULL.
00820  *
00821  * \modifications
00822  *    - 7/14/2005 WSD Created.
00823  */ 
00824 char* fc_getBasenameWOExtension(
00825   char* path,   /**< the path */
00826   int ext_flag  /**< 0 = extension starts at 1st ".", 1 = extentsion starts at
00827             last "." */
00828 ) {
00829   size_t i;
00830   char* temp_str;
00831 
00832   // early return
00833   if (path == NULL)
00834     return NULL;
00835   
00836   // get base
00837   temp_str = fc_getBasename(path);
00838 
00839   // clip off extentions
00840   if (ext_flag == 0) {
00841     for (i = 1; i < strlen(temp_str); i++) {
00842       if (temp_str[i] == '.') {
00843      temp_str[i] = '\0';
00844      break;
00845       }
00846     }
00847   }
00848   else {
00849     for (i = strlen(temp_str); i > 0; i--) {
00850       if (temp_str[i] == '.') {
00851      temp_str[i] = '\0';
00852      break;
00853       }
00854     }
00855   }
00856 
00857   return temp_str;
00858 }
00859 
00860 /**
00861  * \ingroup FilePathUtilities
00862  * \brief Get the extension of path
00863  *
00864  * \description
00865  *
00866  *    Returns the extension of a file if it exists. For example
00867  *    "/usr/local/bin" -> NULL or "../../cherry.txt" -> "txt" or
00868  *    "grumpy.xslt" -> "xslt".
00869  *
00870  *    The user can specify whether the extension starts with the
00871  *    first "." (0) or the last "." (1). For example, "bundle.tar.gz"
00872  *    would be "tar.gz" or ".gz". A leading "." is not treated
00873  *    as an extension ".". For example. ".cshrc" -> "";
00874  *
00875  *    NOTE: If there is no extension, a string is still returned, it
00876  *    just happens to be empty (and you still have to free it).
00877  *
00878  *    User is responsible for freeing the returned string.
00879  *
00880  * \modifications
00881  *    - 7/14/2005 WSD Created.
00882  */ 
00883 char* fc_getExtension(
00884   char* path,   /**< input - the path */
00885   int ext_flag  /**< input - 0 = extension starts at 1st ".", 1 = extentsion 
00886              starts at last "." */
00887 ) {
00888   size_t i;
00889   char* temp_str;
00890   char* ext;
00891   int start = -1;
00892 
00893   // early return
00894   if (path == NULL)
00895     return NULL;
00896 
00897   // get base
00898   temp_str = fc_getBasename(path);
00899   
00900   // find start of extension (".")
00901   if (ext_flag == 0) {
00902     for (i = 1; i < strlen(temp_str); i++) {
00903       if (temp_str[i] == '.') {
00904      start = i;
00905      break;
00906       }
00907     }
00908   }
00909   else {
00910     for (i = strlen(temp_str); i > 0; i--) {
00911       if (temp_str[i] == '.') {
00912      start = i;
00913      break;
00914       }
00915     }
00916   }
00917 
00918   // make the extension
00919   if (start < 0) {
00920     ext = (char*)malloc(sizeof(char));
00921     ext[0] = '\0';
00922   }
00923   else {
00924     ext = (char*)malloc((strlen(temp_str)-start)*sizeof(char));
00925     strcpy(ext, &temp_str[start+1]);
00926   }
00927   free(temp_str);
00928 
00929   return ext;
00930 }
00931 
00932 /**
00933  * \ingroup MiscUtilities
00934  * \brief Compare two ints.
00935  *
00936  * \description
00937  *
00938  *    Compares two ints and returns 1 if the first is greater,
00939  *    0 if they are equal, and -1 if the 2nd is greater.
00940  *    Return values are what routines like qsort expect.
00941  *
00942  * \modifications
00943  *    - 10/10/2005 WSD. Promoted (used to be inside fc_sortIntArray()).
00944  */
00945 int fc_intCompare(const void* n, const void* m) 
00946 {
00947   int a = ((const int*)n)[0];
00948   int b = ((const int*)m)[0];
00949   if (a > b)
00950     return 1;
00951   else if (a < b)
00952     return -1;
00953   else
00954     return 0;
00955 }
00956 
00957 /**
00958  * \ingroup MiscUtilities
00959  * \brief Sort an int array
00960  *
00961  * \description
00962  *
00963  *    Just a wrapper around qsort and fc_intCompare.
00964  *
00965  * \modifications
00966  *    - 07/01/04 WSK Created.
00967  */
00968 FC_ReturnCode fc_sortIntArray(
00969   int num, /**< input - number of entries in array */
00970   int* array /**< input - the array */
00971 ) 
00972 {
00973   if (num < 1 || array == NULL) {
00974     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_INPUT_ERROR));
00975     return FC_INPUT_ERROR;
00976   }  
00977 
00978   qsort((void*)array, (size_t)num, sizeof(int), fc_intCompare);
00979   
00980   return FC_SUCCESS;
00981 }
00982 
00983 /**
00984  * \ingroup MiscUtilities
00985  * \brief  Add a new value to an array of ints.
00986  *
00987  * \description
00988  *  
00989  *    Given an array, the number of elements in the array,
00990  *    and a new value, append the value to the array.
00991  *    The array is assumed to be dynamically generated and the
00992  *    user is responsibly for freeing it when it is no longer
00993  *    in use. The new value is appended to the end and the count is
00994  *    increased by 1.
00995  *    A return value not equal to 0 indicates a failed malloc
00996  *    and the array and the arguments should remain unchanged.
00997  *
00998  * \modifications  
00999  *    - FEB-13-2002  W Koegler  Created.
01000  */
01001 FC_ReturnCode fc_addValueToIntArray(int **array_p, int* num_p, int new_value) {
01002   int *temp_array;
01003 
01004   // check input
01005   if (!array_p || !num_p || *num_p < 0)
01006     return FC_ERROR;
01007 
01008   // copy values & replace array
01009   temp_array = malloc(sizeof(int)*(*num_p + 1));
01010   if (!temp_array) {
01011     fc_printfErrorMessage("%s", fc_getReturnCodeText(FC_MEMORY_ERROR));
01012     return FC_MEMORY_ERROR;
01013   }
01014   if (*num_p > 0) {
01015     memcpy(temp_array, *array_p, sizeof(int)*(*num_p));
01016     free(*array_p);
01017   }
01018   *array_p = temp_array;
01019 
01020   // add new value
01021   (*array_p)[*num_p] = new_value;
01022   (*num_p)++;
01023 
01024   return FC_SUCCESS;
01025 }
01026 
01027 /**
01028  * \ingroup MiscUtilities
01029  * \brief Replace occurances of a char in a string.
01030  *
01031  * \description
01032  *    
01033  *    Return a new string (to be freed by the caller) where occurences
01034  *    of a specified char are replaced with another specified char.
01035  *
01036  *    For example, fc_replaceChar("hi there!", ' ', '_') returns "hi_there!");
01037  */
01038 char* fc_replaceChars(
01039   char* in_string,     /**< input - input string */
01040   char toBeReplaced,   /**< input - char to be replaced */
01041   char replaceWith     /**< input - char to be inserted */
01042 ) {
01043   size_t i, len;
01044   char* temp_string;
01045 
01046   // check input
01047   if (!in_string) 
01048     return NULL;
01049 
01050   // do it
01051   len = strlen(in_string);
01052   temp_string = (char*)malloc((len+1)*sizeof(char));
01053   if (!temp_string)
01054     return NULL;
01055   strcpy(temp_string, in_string);
01056   for (i = 0; i < len; i++)
01057     if (temp_string[i] == toBeReplaced)
01058       temp_string[i] = replaceWith;
01059 
01060   // done
01061   return temp_string;
01062 }
